PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Rio Tinto (RIO AT) lowered guidance on 2019 iron ore output
content:
AUSTRALIA

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT) - Co. CFO Baxby has resigned but will remain with the group until its FY results in October. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. guides H1 RCOP net AUD 120mln-140mln, EBIT AUD 240mln-270mln and states that H1 has presented extraordinary challenges for the industry. (Newswires)

Dacian Gold (DCN AT) - Co. said to allow access to its books for interested buyers and expects the underperforming ball mill at Mt Morgans mine to attract interest, while it announced a new gold discovery in which the results are said to include some of the thickest and highest grade  gold mineralisation intersected at Western Australia. (Newswires)

National Australia Bank (NAB AT) - Co. will allocate AUD 2bln over five years to help emerging tech firms expand. (The Australian)

Resolute Mining (RSG AR) - Co. shares are to be admitted to main market on LSE. (Newswires)

Rio Tinto (RIO AT) - Co. lowered guidance on 2019 iron ore output to 320mln-330mln tons from 333mln-343mln tons, while it noted it was experiencing “operational” difficulties at the Greater Brockman hub. (FT)

Sydney Airport (SYD AT) - Co. May passengers rose 2.4% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Woodside Petroleum (WPL AT) - Canberra may strip the Co. of its ownership of the largest undeveloped gas field in Australia if it doesn’t start cracking on with the project. (The Australian)

 

JAPAN

Daiwa Securities (8601 JT) - Co. is seeking to set up a REIT funded with JPY 100bln as early as FY20. (Nikkei)

Hitachi (6501 JT) - Co. will buy Chassis Brakes in a deal valued at JPY 83bln. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - Co. revised its FY17/18 tax return because JPY 400bln of the JPY 2.0tln loss it booked related to Arm Holdings should not have been booked that year. In other news, Co.’s Vision Fund plans to double the number of "unicorns" in its portfolio within two years but has also flagged a scenario of lower returns for the fund. (Newswires/Nikkei)

Subaru (7270 JT) - Japan National Police Agency placed an order for SUBARU BELL 412EP which is a developmental partnership between Subaru and Bell Helicopter. (Newswires)

Toyota (7203 JT) - Co. is reportedly not pursuing plans for a car plant in Saudi Arabia. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. and Kia Motors (000270 KS) combined May YTD China sales fell 22% Y/Y to 343.4k autos. (Newswires)

Geopolitics - US said it wants talks with North Korea although also rolled out new sanctions against North Korea in which it is targeting a Russian financial firm it accused of providing services to Pyongyang in support of the regime's nuclear weapons program. (Yonhap)

BoK - BoK Governor Lee commented that markets see a heightened chance of US rate cut this year and reiterated that the BoK does not mechanically follow US Fed moves. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea and China held vice-ministerial economic cooperation and early FTA discussions. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS:
content:
FOMC

FOMC left rates unchanged between 2.25-2.50% as expected but tweaked the language in its statement to reflect a more dovish stance. FOMC downgraded its assessment of economic activity to moderate from solid and noted that uncertainties about the outlook have increased. Furthermore, the Fed stated it will closely monitor developments and removed its pledge to be “patient”, while Fed’s Bullard was the only dissenter on rates and favoured a cut.

Fed dot plots showed median forecast is for no change in rates in 2019 although nearly half expected lower rates in which one policymaker forecasts a cut, 7 anticipate two rate cuts, 8 see rates to remain steady and one sees a rate hike. The median view for the Fed Fund Rates in end-2020 is at 2.1% (Prev. 2.6%); end-2021 at 2.4% (Prev. 2.6%) and longer run at 2.5% (Prev. 2.8%). Fed also sees growth slightly stronger in 2020, while jobless rate and inflation are seen slightly lower compared to March projections.

Fed Chair Powell noted at the press conference that many participants see a strong case for rate cuts and that even among the participants who did not see rate cuts, the case for accommodation was stronger now than in the previous meeting. Powell also stated that many participants cited weaker business investment and cross currents as the reason for cuts, while participants also anticipate inflation moving to the target more slowly than expected although he reverted back to the “monitoring” language when explicitly asked about whether the Fed would cut at the upcoming meeting. (Newswires)

Note: Following the decision and press conference, reports noted that 29.5bps of cuts has been priced for July (Prev. 24.9bps) and that 71.5bps of cuts are priced (Prev. 60.5bps) by end-2019. 

 

ASIA-PAC

US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said he will meet with his Chinese counterpart ahead of Trump-Xi meeting at G20 and that it is in the interest of both the US and China to have successful talks. (Newswires)

Chinese Press Editorial suggested there is unlikely to be a quick resolution between Presidents Trump and Xi at the G20 with complex issues such as North Korea, Iran and Huawei also on the agenda. (SCMP)

China Global Times Editor questioned on Twitter whether China and the US are set to have new decisive negotiations and stated that he and the people around him are less optimistic than they were when the two leaders met last December, while he believes Trump's call is a result of the fight from the Chinese side and that more battles may be needed for making the US fairer. (Twitter)

 

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson maintained the lead in the third Conservative leadership vote with 143 votes vs. Jeremy Hunt at 54 votes, Michael Gove at 51 votes, Sajid Javid at 38 votes and Rory Stewart who was eliminated with 27 votes. (Newswires)

ECB's VP de Guindos (Neutral) noted that the ECB could opt for a combination of actions to restore inflation and that QE is among the wide range of tools available. (Newswires)

UK CPI (May) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

 

FX

SNB Quarterly Bulletin stated the Swiss economy grew solidly in the second quarter with normal utilisation of production capacity, while it added that the main risks come from the effects of trade barriers and many company representatives voiced concerns about the situation on the real estate market. (Newswires)

Canadian CPI (May) Y/Y 2.4% vs. Exp. 2.1% (Prev. 2.0%). (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks -3.106M vs. Exp. -1.077M (Prev. 2.206M). (Newswires)

UAE Energy Minister said the country supports a decision to extend OPEC+ production cuts and that an extension to the cuts is reasonable as the market's position requires it. (Al Bayan)

OPEC sources noted that future OPEC/OPEC+ meetings and decisions may be even more fraught amid the conflict among the oil producers. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran will take a second step to reduce compliance with nuclear deal and can solve the issue of exporting oil, while it is said to be in talks with Russia and China on a settlement mechanism in case talks with EU fails, according sources. (Tass)

 

US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said President Trump intends to keep the government open and that the White House will propose a one-year continuing resolution as well debt limit hike if no deal is made. (CNBC)

Potential Fed nominee Shelton said she would like to see lower rates as fast as possible. (Washington Post)

 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) opened higher on reports that it has asked major suppliers to look into the potential costs of moving 15%-30% of production capacity away from China towards Southeast Asia, as the iPhone maker prepares to restructure its supply chain. Boeing (BA) received a large number of orders for its aircrafts, including for the grounded 737 MAX, at the Paris Air Show. Merck (MRK) edged higher on reports the drug maker is looking to secure small and midsize deals, which are primarily aimed at a further expansion of its portfolio of cancer treatments. Adobe (ADBE) shot higher on earnings that beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines, shrugging off weaker EPS guidance. Amazon (AMZN) is looking to add a number of smaller aircraft to its rental fleet, as the ecommerce giant looks to expand its next-day delivery capacity. FedEx (FDX) moved lower, having recently opted to end its shipping agreement with Amazon, in order to focus on other retailers. Facebook (FB) opened red after US House Banking Chair Waters requested it halt development of its new Libra cryptocurrency until Congress and regulators can review it. TripAdvisor (TRIP) caught a bid after it was upgraded to Buy from Hold at Suntrust. American Express (AXP) jumped higher pre-market after the payments co. received an upgrade from BAML, with Mastercard (MA) moving higher in sympathy, quite possibly due to the positive industry trends cited by the broker. Allergan (AGN) and Ironwood Pharmaceuticals (IRWD) both jumped higher up as their LIZNESS drug met primary endpoints in a Phase 3 trial. CBS Corp (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) both moved higher on the news that the former may make an offer within the next few weeks. Axalta (AXTA) surged on reports the co. is looking to explore a potential sale. Redhat (RHT) shot higher after the co.’s merger with IBM was approved by EU regulators. S&P 500 0.3% at 2926, NASDAQ-100 0.4% at 7668, Dow Jones 0.2% at 26504.

The Treasury curve bull-steepened after a dovish FOMC meeting, where the Fed held rates though tweaked its guidance in a dovish manner, and reiterated a willingness to act if the situation required. The near-end of the Treasury yield curve saw further lows (2s see a 1.5yr low, 3s nearly a 20-month low), though the 10-year note again is clinging to a 2-handle at settlement, though it is only a couple of basis points from going under 2%. At settlement, 2s30s was nearly 8bps wider. In terms of pricing for Fed cuts, 29.5bps of cuts has been priced for July (vs 24.9bps prior to today's rate decision); by end 2019, 71.5bps of cuts are priced (vs 60.5bps before the rate decision). US T-note futures (U9) settled 11+ ticks higher at 127-27+.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 19th June 2019: Fed holds rates, opens door to more accommodation
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Fed holds rate, makes dovish statement tweaks; USTR Lighthizer to talk with Chinese counterpart as trade hopes rise; Canada CPI rises sharply.
  • COMING UP: RBA’s Lowe; ECB’s de Guindos, Rehn; Norges Bank; UK Retail Sales; BoE; BoE’s Carney; US Initial Jobless Claims, Leading Index Change; BoJ.

 

* FOMC REVIEW: FOMC left rates unchanged between 2.25-2.50%, as expected, but tweaked the language in its statement to reflect a more dovish stance. It downgraded its assessment of economic activity to “moderate” from “solid” previously. It also noted that “uncertainties about the outlook have increased” and the FOMC will “closely monitor” developments, and removed its pledge to be “patient” as it determined the appropriateness of rates. Analysts have immediately taken the latest tweaks as a sign that the FOMC has opened the door to future rate cuts, if required. In the aftermath, risk assets rallied in a manner consistent with a loosening of financial conditions (stocks up, yields down, dollar down, while gold rallied). During the press conference, Powell noted that even among the participants who did not see rate cuts, the case for accommodation was stronger now than in the previous meeting. Powell was explicitly asked about whether the Fed would cut at the upcoming meeting, and Powell reverted back to the “monitoring” language, suggesting that the Committee will be taking a wait and see approach, and the rate decision will hinge on the outcome of trade talks. However, Powell was asked whether a trade deal between US/China would diminish the case for cuts, and he stated that the Fed does not just monitor one development, citing global growth as another factor that the Fed is cognizant of, as well as inflation and jobs growth. Powell reiterated the Fed’s readiness to act promptly, if needed, to sustain the economic expansion. On the increment of future rate cuts, Powell said that the FOMC had not yet engaged with the question of whether it should be 25bps or 50bps, reverting back to incoming data, and how overall risks evolve. Powell was asked about the risks of waiting too long, but does not feel these risks are prominent now. On inflation (PCE inflation forecast cut to 1.5% form 1.8%), Powell said that fall in breakeven rates was a factor that boosted the case for rate cuts, arguing that the Fed does not want to be seen as weak on inflation. Regarding the balance sheet, Powell said that the run-off is close to the end of its planned life; if the Fed were to provide more accommodation, it would be willing to adjust balance sheet policy. On political influence, Powell firmly stated that he fully intends to serve his four-year term. However, soon after the conclusion of the FOMC presser, CNBC’s Gasparino hinted that US President Trump will try to remove him if he does a 180 on rates, citing people close to the President.

* US/CHINA: There were further positive signs that US and Chinese policymakers are making progress ahead of the G20 meeting on 28-29th June, where Presidents Xi and Trump will have an extended meeting in an effort to get trade talks back on track. USTR Lighthizer is set to have a telephone conversation with his Chinese counterpart, and said it was in the interest of both the US and China to have successful talks. Lighthizer’s comments did not make clear when negotiations will formerly restart. CNBC, citing analysts with ties to the Chinese government, said that there is a view that US President Donald Trump is ready to move toward an agreement. There was a more circumspect approach in China, where an editorial in SCMP stated that a quick resolution between the two sides was unlikely at the G20, with complex issues such as North Korea, Iran and Huawei also on the agenda. China Global Times Editor was also sceptical, asking "are China and the US set to have new decisive negotiations? People around me and myself are less optimistic than we were when two leaders met last December." He also said he believes Trump's call is a result of fight of Chinese side and more battles may be needed for making the US (act) fairer. In early trade, it was reported that China’s MOFCOM has today launched an anti-dumping investigation into some rubber products from South Korea, EU and the US.

* CANADA CPI: An upside surprise, which saw the headline YY rate accelerate to 2.4% from 2.0% (exp. 2.1%), and the core Y/Y rate rise to 2.1% from 1.5%. An average of the three BOC core measures rose to 2.06% from 1.90% in the previous report. Headline inflation, therefore, rises above the BOC’s target for the first time since last October. “This should provide the Bank some comfort with its current policy stance and allow them to push back against market pricing for cuts,” TD Securities said, “however, any potential rate hikes are still a long-ways off, with a number of obstacles to clear beforehand.” TD adds that “this will undoubtedly add to the evolving BOC narrative of things ‘looking up’ and hence, some CAD optimism. However, the hurdle is high for us to clear this mark in our view, and we require a material pick-up in activity data and reduced threat of easing (in the Fed as well as the BOC) to validate that sentiment.”

* WTI FUTURES (N9) SETTLE USD 0.14 LOWER AT USD 53.76/BBL; BRENT FUTURES (Q9) SETTLE USD 0.32 LOWER AT USD 61.82/BBL: Crude markets drifted lower through the session, relatively unphased by the FOMC and experiencing some volatility from a bullish inventory report. There was a short-lived spike on the release of the EIA US inventory data, which saw crude stocks draw 3.1mln bbls, larger than the expected 1.1mln bbl draw, as well as the 0.8mln bbl draw provided by the API; Cushing stocks built by 0.64mln bbls. In the products, both gasoline and distillates printed surprise draws of 1.7mln bbls and 0.55mln bbls respectively. Elsewhere, OPEC+ have struck and agreement to hold its upcoming meeting on July 1st-2nd (OPEC July 1st, OPEC+ July 2nd). OPEC sources later suggested that future meetings and decisions may be even more fraught amid the conflict among the producers; While not necessarily new or surprising, it does highlight the difficulty on the agreement of production cuts, particularly raised cuts or extended cuts into 2020.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLED 11+ TICKS HIGHER AT 127-27+: The Treasury curve bull-steepened after a dovish FOMC meeting, where the Fed held rates though tweaked its guidance in a dovish manner, and reiterated a willingness to act if the situation required. The near-end of the Treasury yield curve saw further lows (2s see a 1.5yr low, 3s nearly a 20-month low), though the 10-year note again is clinging to a 2-handle at settlement, though it is only a couple of basis points from going under 2%. At settlement, 2s30s was nearly 8bps wider. In terms of pricing for Fed cuts, 29.5bps of cuts has been priced for July (vs 24.9bps prior to today's rate decision); by end 2019, 71.5bps of cuts are priced (vs 60.5bps before the rate decision).

* S&P 500 0.3% at 2926, NASDAQ-100 0.4% at 7668, Dow Jones 0.2% at 26504, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 0.2%, Consumer Staples 0.4%, Energy -0.2%, Financials -0.2%, Health Care 1%, Industrials 0%, Information Technology 0.4%, Materials -0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.2%, Utilities 0.8%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) opened higher on reports that it has asked major suppliers to look into the potential costs of moving 15%-30% of production capacity away from China towards Southeast Asia, as the iPhone maker prepares to restructure its supply chain. Boeing (BA) received a large number of orders for its aircrafts, including for the grounded 737 MAX, at the Paris Air Show. Merck (MRK) edged higher on reports the drug maker is looking to secure small and midsize deals, which are primarily aimed at a further expansion of its portfolio of cancer treatments. Adobe (ADBE) shot higher on earnings that beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines, shrugging off weaker EPS guidance. Amazon (AMZN) is looking to add a number of smaller aircraft to its rental fleet, as the ecommerce giant looks to expand its next-day delivery capacity. FedEx (FDX) moved lower, having recently opted to end its shipping agreement with Amazon, in order to focus on other retailers. Facebook (FB) opened red after US House Banking Chair Waters requested it halt development of its new Libra cryptocurrency until Congress and regulators can review it. TripAdvisor (TRIP) caught a bid after it was upgraded to Buy from Hold at Suntrust. American Express (AXP) jumped higher pre-market after the payments co. received an upgrade from BAML, with Mastercard (MA) moving higher in sympathy, quite possibly due to the positive industry trends cited by the broker. Allergan (AGN) and Ironwood Pharmaceuticals (IRWD) both jumped higher up as their LIZNESS drug met primary endpoints in a Phase 3 trial. CBS Corp (CBS) and Viacom (VIAB) both moved higher on the news that the former may make an offer within the next few weeks. Axalta (AXTA) surged on reports the co. is looking to explore a potential sale. Redhat (RHT) shot higher after the co.’s merger with IBM was approved by EU regulators.

* FX WRAP: USD moved lower after the Fed opted to hold rates but made substantial dovish tweaks to its statement, whilst the dot plot indicated that 7 voters were calling for 2 rate cuts in 2019 (although the median for 2019 was still to hold rates); with DXY bottoming out at 97.10. EUR erased yesterday’s post Draghi losses, with EURUSD making fresh weekly highs at 1.1254 in the aftermath of the FOMC. Likewise, JPY also gained as the dollar came off, but failed to break out of its recent 107.80-108.80 range, with gains capped amid improved US/China trade related optimism. CHF performed better, USDCHF reversing recent gains back to parity and moving as low as 0.9917 on the day. As ever, the SNB will be monitoring, ready to respond should the Franc become too highly valued. GBP gained against the weaker greenback, but struggled against the EUR, after broadly in line UK inflation data did little to move the needle at tomorrow’s BoE MPC meeting, (although Core CPI moved higher) and Boris Johnson maintained his lead in the latest round of conservative leadership voting. CAD popped higher after CPI data came in above expectations. AUD was under pressure in early trade, despite skilled vacancies rising overnight, (although, the trend is still downwards) amid an RBA on the lookout for labour market improvement, but made a comeback vs USD after the FOMC, AUDUSD briefly reaching back above 0.6900. SocGen has suggested the 0.6875 region could be a floor after signs of progress on US/China trade and the dovish FOMC. NZD also moved higher vs the buck, reversing earlier declines, which came despite a bigger than expected surplus reported overnight and tailwinds from US/China trade optimism. KRW, which is seen as a solid indicator of EM-Asia export demand, benefited overnight from movement on the US/China front ahead of the 28-29th June G20 meeting. EMFX rallied on the weaker buck. Optimism ahead of the G20 has helped CNH catch up with CNY, while there could be further short covering on the cards. TRY managed to pare the worst of losses prompted after US President Trump threatened US sanctions against Turkey over the impending arrival of S-400 missiles from Russia, as CBRT minutes reaffirmed disinflationary factors and a determination to deploy all tools to combat threats to CPI deviating from its gradual path towards target. Meanwhile, ZAR was able to derive some traction after above consensus SA CPI, ahead of tomorrow’s State of the Union address from President Ramaphosa. BRL traded subdued prior to the Fed, as traders look ahead to the BCB rate decision, due after market.

subject: FED CHAIR POWELL PRESSER: Saw no strong case for adjusting policy rate; notes uncertainties around trade
content:
On rates/policy

  • Many participants see a strong case for rate cuts
  • Even participants who saw no cuts said the case for accommodation is stronger now
  • Will use tools as appropriate, and promptly, to sustain the economic expansion
  • Not looking at one particular thing when considering rate cuts (when asked about a China trade deal)
  • The risk of waiting too long on policy change is not prominent now
  • Has not yet engaged in the question of whether a rate cut should be 25bps or 50bps

On balance sheet

  • Balance sheet runoff is close to the end of its planned life
  • If Fed provided more accommodation, would keep in mind that it is willing to adjust the balance sheet policy

On inflation

  • Many participants see inflation coming to target more slowly than expected
  • Rising wages are not providing upward push on inflation; global factors might hold down inflation
  • Growth and lower inflation expectations created concerns over sustained shortfall in inflation
  • The fall in inflation securities was one factor boosting the case for rate cuts in the future; inflation has concerned Powell for some time
  • Fed wont look at raising inflation target because its become a global norm; is looking at less radical ideas

On outlook

  • Labour market indicators remain strong
  • Many participants cited weaker business investment and cross currents as the reason for cuts
  • Says he is sure things could change before the next meeting

On politics

  • Says he fully intends to serve his four year term
  • Fed doesn’t target the exchange rate, says that is a question for the Treasury

subject: SNAP ANALYSIS: FOMC tweaks statement dovishly, but median still sees rates unchanged in 2019, suggesting it will take a wait and see approach on trade developments
content: FOMC left rates unchanged between 2.25-2.50%, as expected, but tweaked the language in its statement to reflect a more dovish stance. It downgraded its assessment of economic activity to “moderate” from “solid” previously. It also noted that “uncertainties about the outlook have increased” and the FOMC will “closely monitor” developments, and removing its pledge to be “patient” as it determined the appropriateness of rates. Analysts have immediately taken the latest tweaks as a sign that the FOMC has opened the door to future rate cuts, if required. There was no mention of any tweaks to the balance sheet plan. In the aftermath, risk assets rallied in a manner consistent with a loosening of financial conditions (stocks up, yields down, dollar down, while gold rallied).

subject: FOMC DOT PLOT: June 2019
FOMC FORECAST TABLE: June 2019
FOMC STATEMENT CHANGES: June 2019
FOMC STATEMENT CHANGES: June 2019
FOMC STATEMENT: Fed leaves rates unchanged, median forecast is for no change in rates seen in 2019, but nearly half see lower rates
content:
On rates/policy

  • Fed leaves rates unchanged, median forecast is for no change in rates seen in 2019, but nearly half see lower rates
  • One policymaker sees a cut in 2019 and seven see two rate cuts; eight see rates steady and one sees a rate hike
  • St. Louis Fed President Bullard was the only dissenter, who favoured a rate cut
  • Fed drops "patient" from statement on future policy adjustments
  • Median view of Fed Funds Rate at end of 2020 is 2.1% (prev. 2.6%); end of 2021 is 2.4% (prev. 2.6%); longer run is 2.5% (prev. 2.8%)

On outlook 

  • Sees growth slightly stronger in 2020, jobless rate and inflation are seen slightly lower, compared to march projections
  • Median Fed long-run forecasts: GDP growth 1.9% (prev. 1.9%); jobless rate 4.2% (prev. 4.3%); PCE Price Index 2.0% (prev. 2.0%)
  • Fed says uncertainties have increased regarding the outlook for sustained economic expansion; will act as appropriate to sustain the expansions with a strong labour market and inflation near target level
  • Fed says economic activity is rising at a moderate rate; household spending appears to have picked up but business fixed investment has been soft

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar drifts into FOMC, mulling how dovish Fed will be
content:
USD

The Greenback remains mixed vs major rivals and rather jittery overall as the DXY hovers around 97.500 and the clock ticks down to the FOMC, SEP and post-meeting conference from Chair Powell. The market anticipates or rather expects a dovish message and has priced in a 25 cut in July at the very least, while the external pressure is mounting to the extent that US President Trump is almost demanding looser policy, especially after ECB President effectively flagged more stimulus on the eve of the latest Fed decision. Technically, not much either side of the 97.683-393 range before the 97.802 mtd high and 96.873, which was last Thursday’s low, aside the psychological 97.000 level if Powell and co match or surpass expectations.

GBP/CHF

Extending earlier outperformance as the Buck slips pretty much across the board, with Cable rebounding through 1.2600 and clearing a couple of near term technical levels (like Monday’s peak and the 100 HMA) on the way to a circa 1.2635 recovery high. Meanwhile, EUR/Gbp has pulled back further from around 0.8975 at one stage on Tuesday and under 0.8900, as the single currency pivots 1.1200 and struggles to clear mega expiries spanning the big figure even after the NY cut in wake of ECB President Draghi’s decidedly dovish musings yesterday. Note, Sterling climbed after broadly in line UK inflation data earlier and ahead of the BoE, but may get further independent impetus when results of the 3rd Tory leadership vote appear (from 18.00BST) Elsewhere, Eur/Chf is slipping deeper below 1.1200 alongside Usd/Chf towards 0.9950, but the SNB will be monitoring the situation and ready to respond if the Franc becomes more than highly valued.

CAD/NZD/AUD

The Loonie is off best levels, but still relatively firm vs its US counterpart and Antipodean currency peers following firmer than forecast Canadian CPI data and a hefty headline y/y beat in particular. Usd/Cad currently hovering above 1.3350 within a 1.3337-83 range and back up near decent expiry interest between 1.3350-70 (1.2 bn) before they rolled off. Conversely, the Aussie and Kiwi are looking more nervous pre-FOMC and in advance of Q1 NZ GDP before a speech from RBA Governor Lowe in the early hours on Thursday. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd now circa 0.6870 and 0.6525 and both towards the base of 0.6856-85 and 0.6515-38 bands.

JPY 

The Yen has been largely restricted vs the Dollar in 108.25-61 parameters and also awaiting the Fed ahead of the BoJ, with expiries in the mix from 108.00 and then 108.30-40 in 2.95 bn and 1.3 bn respectively.

EM

The Real is on a weaker footing vs the Greenback in line with broader trends across the region and looking towards the BCB for some non-Fed inspiration via forward guidance given that the Selic rate is seen on hold and 2 eases are anticipated before the end of 2019 at present. Meanwhile, the Rand has derived some traction from above consensus SA CPI ahead of tomorrow’s State of the Union address from President Ramaphosa. Last, but not least (as usual), the Lira also pared worst losses prompted by more threats of US sanctions against Turkey over the impending arrival of S-400 missiles from Russia as CBRT minutes reaffirmed disinflationary factors and a determination to deploy all tools to combat threats to CPI deviating from its gradual path towards target. Usd/Brl, Usd/Zar and Usd/Try near 3.8720, 14.5130 and 5.8400 respectively.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 19th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

DOW

  • American Express (AXP) (Financials/Consumer Finance) was reiterated with a “buy” at BAML, who note the company’s strong brand and point to several positive factors including card fee increases and portfolio growth.
  • Apple (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is reportedly asking major suppliers to look into the potential costs of moving 15%-30% of production capacity to Southeast Asia, away from China, as the iPhone maker prepares to restructure its supply chain, reported Nikkei. The request was comes in response to the recent bout of US/China trade tensions, but reportedly multiple sources are suggesting that even if the trade war is resolved, "there will be no turning back", Apple having decided the risks of being heavily reliant on Chinese manufacturing are "too great and even rising."

Boeing (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence)/Airbus (EADSY, AIR FP) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence):

*         Airbus made a 50-plane deal with low-cost airline Indigo Partners, bouncing back from a slow day yesterday at the Paris Air Show, in which IAG placed an order for up to 200 of Boeing's grounded 737 MAX jets.

*         The most recent tallies: Airbus has sold 281 aircraft worth USD 33.9bln (selling A321XLRs, A320 & A321neos, and A220-300s) whilst Boeing has sold 236 aircraft valued at USD 35.6bln (737s, 787s and 777 freighters).

*         Yesterday’s Boeing deals (including aircraft & services sales): IAG for 200 Boeing 737-8 and 737-10 aircraft (USD 24bln), China Airlines for 6 Boeing 777 freighters, JetBlue & United for crew management solutions, ASL for 20 737-800 Boeing converted freighters, Qatar Airways for 5 Boeing 777 Freighters (USD 1.8bln), Turkmenistan Airlines for 1 Boeing 777-200LR.

*         Elsewhere, efforts to get the Boeing’s 737 MAX aircrafts operating have reportedly been delayed in part by concerns about whether the average pilot has enough physical strength to turn a manual crank in extreme emergencies, reported the WSJ citing sources.

*         Separately, the US is expected to be open to talks regarding "enforceable mechanisms". These may allow Airbus to receive government funding on commercial terms whilst easing the risk of tit-for-tat sanctions between the US/EU, reported newswires.

  • Merck & Co (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals), in wake of recent approval of its Keytruda cancer drug, is reportedly looking to secure small and midsize deals, which are primarily aimed at a further expansion of its portfolio of cancer treatments, reported the WSJ. Elsewhere, AstraZeneca (AZN, AZN LN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Merck & Co announced that Japan's PMDA has approved the co.’s joint LYNPARZA drug, which is a maintenance treatment for patients with ovarian cancer. The approval was based on solid data from a Phase 3 trial evaluating LYNPARZA compared with a placebo.

NASDAQ 100

  • Adobe (ADBE) (Information Technology/Application Software) (USD) reports Q2 2019 adj. EPS 1.83 (exp. 1.78), revenue 2.74bln (exp. 2.7bln); sees Q3 EPS at 1.95 (exp. 2.05), Q3 revenue seen at 2.8bln (exp. 2.82bln).
  • Alphabet’s (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) Google Cloud is to expand its strategic partnership with HP Enterprise (HPE) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals), in order to provide hybrid cloud solutions. Elsewhere, CEO Pichai announced via blog post that the technology co will commit USD 1bln in a bid to boost home construction in the San Francisco Bay Area.
  • Amazon.com (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly looking to adding a number of smaller aircraft to its rental fleet, as the ecommerce giant looks to expand its next-day delivery capacity, reported the WSJ. The decision reportedly came after FedEx (FDX) (Industrials/Air Freight & Logistics) opted to end its shipping agreement with the co. in order to focus on other retailers.
  • Dish Network (DISH) (Communication Services/Media) is in talks to pay a minimum of USD 6bln for divested T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communication Services/Media) and Sprint (S) (Communication Services/Media) assets, which the two telecoms co.s are selling as in order to obtain regulatory approval for their proposed merger from the DoJ.
  • Facebook (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) - US House Banking Chair Waters has requested that the social media co. halt development of its new Libra cryptocurrency, until Congress and regulators can review it.
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) HR vice president/head of diversity Mayo has left the company, adding to the tally of executive resignations in the last year, reported CNBC.

S&P 500

  • Allergan (AGN) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and Ironwood (IRWD) (Health Care/Biotechnology) have announced positive topline data from a Phase 3b clinical trial, which evaluated the effectiveness of LINZESS multiple abdominal symptoms in adult patients with IBS-C. The trial met its primary multi-component endpoint, demonstrating an improvement in overall abdominal symptoms including bloating, pain and discomfort compared to placebo.
  • CBS Corp’s (CBS) (Communication Services/Broadcasting) board discussed making an offer to recombine with Viacom (VIAB) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) at a meeting last week, reported the WSJ. An offer could be made in the coming weeks, however, representatives of both companies have already had preliminary talks about the outlines of a deal, though determining the price for a stock transaction is one "major hurdle," the report stated.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is allegedly looking to hire more temp workers at its US factories in a bid to cut health care costs.
  • Raytheon (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defence) announced a new strategic agreement with AirMap, in which the two co.s will collaborate on future projects that aim to safely integrate drones into the national airspace system. The partnership aims to unlock the potential positive economic and social benefits of expanded commercial drone operations. Elsewhere, Raytheon’s AIM-9x block II missile hit its target in its first flight from a Nasams launcher.
  • Southwest Airlines (LUV) (Industrials/Airlines) has raised its Q2 RASM (revenue per available seat mile) view to 6.5%-7.5% from 5.5%-7.5%, owing to “solid” demand. The Q2 capacity guidance reflects the impact of the grounding of all of the airlines 34 737 MAX aircraft until 5 August.

OTHER

  • Adidas’ (ADDYY, ADS GY) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) black employees at the apparel maker’s North American HQ feel “ignored” and “discriminated against”, reported the NYT. Less than 4.5% workers at co.’s headquarters identify as black.
  • Nissan (NSANY, 7201 JT) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) is looking to create a new board committee which will include seats for the chairman and CEO of partner Renault (RNSDF, RNO FP) (), as the Japanese carmaker looks to avoid conflict with its French counterpart at an upcoming shareholders meeting, reported Nikkei. Elsewhere, several of Renault and Nissan's joint departments are being axed and staff being laid off, as the two automakers' alliance continues to break down in the absence of Carlos Ghosn, reported the FT.
  • PG&E (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) has agreed to pay USD 1bln to some Californian communities to settle wildfire claims, reported the WSJ.
  • Samsung (SSNLF, 005930 KS) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) is set to launch its new Galaxy Note 10 on 7 August at an event in New York's Barclays Centre, reported CNET.
  • Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson (ERIC, ERICB SS) (Communication Services/Media) has announced a partnership with GCI (GLIBA) (Communication Services/Media) to build a 5G network in Anchorage, Alaska.

  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI, US DoEs, FOMC rate decision and Fed Chair Powell press conference, NZ GDP, ECB’s Coeure, Draghi 

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets rallied across the board as the region followed suit from the heightened global risk appetite due to a double dosage of optimism from ECB President Draghi’s hints of potential easing and after US President Trump confirmed a meeting with his Chinese counterpart at the G20. ASX 200 (+1.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.8%) were higher with Australia led by energy names after a surge in oil prices and with outperformance also seen in the trade sensitive industries such as tech, materials and miners, while the Japanese benchmark gapped above the 21K level fuelled by favourable currency flows and strength in commodity-related sectors. Hang Seng (+2.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.0%) were buoyed after US President Trump announced the resumption of US-China trade talks and that he will be conducting an extended meeting with Chinese President Xi at the G20 following “a very good” telephone conversation between the 2 leaders, while the PBoC were also supportive with the announcement of liquidity injections through reverse repos and its medium-term lending facility. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher after the dovish comments from ECB’s Draghi added to the declining global yields narrative which saw a drop in 10yr JGB yields to their lowest since August 2016, while the BoJ also kick starts its 2-day policy meeting where they are expected to maintain current policy settings and reaffirm guidance of keeping rates at very low interest rate levels for an extended period of time at least through around Spring 2020.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 240bln through 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8893 (Prev. 6.8942) 

UK/EU

UK Labour party leader Corbyn will reportedly back a move for Labour to support a 2nd referendum in all circumstances. (Times)

UK CPI YY (May) 2.0% vs. Exp. 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%) (Newswires) - Air fares fell in May following Easter highs in April - Overall rate of inflation generally steady since the start of the year

EQUITIES

European equities are tentative [Eurostoxx 50 Unch] as the region gears up for the FOMC rate decision later today (Full preview available in the Research Suite). Sectors are mixed, underperformance is seen in defensive stocks with healthcare, utilities and consumer staples all lower. In terms of movers, STMicroelectronics (+3.2%) and Infineon (+2.7%) shares gained following a broker move at Morgan Stanley and Bernstein respectively. On the flip side, Steinhoff (-6.5%) opened at the foot of the Stoxx 600 after the Co.’s delayed 2018 results posted losses, whilst Belgian retailer Colruyt (-12.2%) plunged on disappointing earnings

FX

DXY - Relatively tight lines being drawn ahead of the FOMC in G10 land, as is often the case, but the Greenback has clawed back some losses against EMs after Tuesday’s euphoria over the US and China reopening lines of communication on the trade front. However, the index is braced for the Fed within a confined 97.683-553 range, and seemingly reluctant to breach chart/psychological resistance or support around 97.639 (61.8% Fib retracement of pull-back from 98.373 ytd peak to recent 96.451 low) and 97.500 respectively in the run up – see the Ransquawk Research Suite for a full preview.

GBP/CHF - Bucking the overall muted trend, Cable has continued its recovery towards 1.2600 after broadly in line with forecast UK CPI and PPI data and ahead of the BoE tomorrow, while Eur/Gbp has also retraced further to test 0.8900 compared to circa 0.8975 before ECB President Draghi’s apparent dovish Sintra revelations. Similarly, the Franc is consolidating back above parity and over 1.1200 vs the single currency as markets tread more cautiously in wake of yesterday’s risk-on session.

EUR/JPY/CAD/AUD/NZD - All narrowly mixed vs the Buck, as noted above, with the Euro licking wounds inflicted by latest dovish ECB vibes and back on the 1.1200 handle where extremely heavy option expiry interest is anchored (5.2 bn 10 pips either side of the big figure). The Yen is also wary of BoJ guidance skewed towards ongoing or even more stimulus, and bound by hefty expiries as 2.95 bn rolls off at the 108.00 strike and 1.3 bn between 108.30-40 vs the 108.25-61 range so far. Elsewhere, the Loonie awaits Canadian CPI data and is holding above 1.3400 with decent expiries from 1.3350-70 (1.2 bn) in close proximity, while the Aussie and Kiwi are both maintaining their recovery momentum over 0.6850 and 0.6500 respectively ahead of RBA Governor Lowe and NZ Q1 GDP, with the former not unduly ruffled by the latest in a growing list of calls for more rate cuts.

EM - The Lira is back on the rack and underperforming amidst the general retracement noted above, and the renewed threat of US sanctions against Turkey has lifted Usd/Try off recent lows to 5.9150+ at one stage. Elsewhere, the Rand has unwound some of its Eskom-related outsize gains despite firmer the forecast SA CPI, with Usd/Zar rebounding through 14.5000.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have succumbed to a bit more long liquidation, profit taking and/or pre-Fed hedging in case Powell and co confound market expectations and do not yield to mounting external pressure for looser monetary policy. The core 10 year benchmarks all slipped to new intraday lows before finding some underlying bids, at 172.20, 130.19 and 127-08+ respectively and it remains to be seen whether this marks the extent of debt consolidation and rebalancing after yesterday’s pronounced rally and arguably exaggerated moves.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are marginally lower on the day as yesterday’s upbeat sentiment in the complex somewhat wanes ahead of today’s DoE release. Last night’s API numbers showed a slightly narrower-than-forecast draw in crude stocks (-0.81mln vs. Exp. -1.1mln) . Traders will be keeping an eye on the more widely followed DoE numbers for any short term direction (crude stocks expected to draw by 1.077mln barrels), ahead of tonight’s FOMC meeting. On the OPEC front, the oil producers have decided to hold the OPEC meeting on July 1st and the OPEC+ meeting on the 2nd following weeks of indecisiveness. Elsewhere, gold is unwinding some of its risk premium amid President Trump and his Chinese counterpart showed willingness to reignite US-Sino trade talks at the G20, albeit the yellow metal is certain to be swayed by tonight’s Fed meeting and presser. Meanwhile, copper is little changed but holds onto most of its trade-driven gains. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures spiked higher by almost 6% as the base metal followed the broad rally across assets.

OPEC will hold its meeting on July 1st-2nd, according to an OPEC delegate. (Newswires)

OPEC will need to extend the output cut deal as inventories are rising, according to UAE official. (Newswires)

Iranian Oil Minister said Europe is not assisting in purchasing Iranian oil, according to Fars News. (Fars)

Reports note a rocket hit a foreign oil company headquarters in Basra, Iraq. However, officials later stated that Iraq's southern oil operations and exports were not impacted by the rocket incident. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Chinese Commerce Ministry says they will today launch an anti-dumping investigation into some rubber products from South Korea, EU and US. (Newswires)

US President Trump is considering sanctions on Turkey for purchasing Russian S-400s. (Newswires)

Iran considers engaging foreign potential to reinforce its domestic capacity in air defence, according to Sputnik citing Iran's Supreme National Security Council. (Newswires)

UN Rights Investigator has found credible evidence linking high-level Saudi officials to Journalist Kashoggi's murder, which includes Saudi Crown Prince Bin Salman. (Newswires)

content: No real surprise to see a bout of consolidation given the magnitude of gains forged on another landmark Sintra speech from ECB President Draghi and the subsequent risk-supportive news that US-China trade talks will resume ahead of the G20 where Presidents Trump and Xi will hold extended talks in an effort to resolve differences. Moreover, pre-FOMC positioning favours a cautious/defensive approach on the premise that so much easing is already factored in and the danger is disappointment if the Fed fails to deliver. Back to the ECB, Lautenschlager and Coeure set the stage for closing conference remarks from Draghi. Also ahead, Eurozone current account and construction output, plus relatively small 2046 German supply. Bunds meandering between 172.55-72 vs yesterday’s 172.86 close and 172.88 contract peak, 10 year yield circa -31 bp.

  • Asian equity markets rallied across the board as the region followed suit from the heightened global risk appetite
  • Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson remained in the lead after the second round of the Conservative leadership vote
  • DXY was steady and remained near this month’s highs after the recent Draghi-induced selling in EUR/USD
  • US President Trump replied "let's see what he does" when asked whether he wants to demote Fed Chair Powell
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK and Canadian CPI, US DoEs, FOMC rate decision and Fed Chair Powell press conference, NZ GDP, BoJ’s Kuroda, ECB’s Lautenschlager, Coeure, Draghi, Germany 2046 Bund

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets rallied across the board as the region followed suit from the heightened global risk appetite due to a double dosage of optimism from ECB President Draghi’s hints of potential easing and after US President Trump confirmed a meeting with his Chinese counterpart at the G20. ASX 200 (+1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.7%) were higher with Australia led by energy names after a surge in oil prices and with outperformance also seen in the trade sensitive industries such as tech, materials and miners, while the Japanese benchmark gapped above the 21K level fuelled by favourable currency flows and strength in commodity-related sectors. Hang Seng (+2.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.5%) were buoyed after US President Trump announced the resumption of US-China trade talks and that he will be conducting an extended meeting with Chinese President Xi at the G20 following “a very good” telephone conversation between the 2 leaders, while the PBoC were also supportive with the announcement of liquidity injections through reverse repos and its medium-term lending facility. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher after the dovish comments from ECB’s Draghi added to the declining global yields narrative which saw a drop in 10yr JGB yields to their lowest since August 2016, while the BoJ also kick starts its 2-day policy meeting where they are expected to maintain current policy settings and reaffirm guidance of keeping rates at very low interest rate levels for an extended period of time at least through around Spring 2020.

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 240bln through 1yr Medium-term Lending Facility. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8893 (Prev. 6.8942)

US President Trump said US and China want to discuss the future and repeated that he has a very good relationship with China’s President. Trump also commented that negotiating teams will start talks today and reiterated the US will have a fair deal with China or no deal at all. (Newswires)

USTR Lighthizer reaffirmed no decision has yet been made on implementing the next round of tariffs on Chinese goods, while he suggested that dialogue has proven to be unsuccessful in achieving trade reform with China and that he is unsure if tariffs alone will stop China cheating but it is the best instrument available. (Newswires) 

UK/EU

Former UK Foreign Minister Boris Johnson remained in the lead after the second round of the Conservative leadership vote with 126 votes vs. Jeremy Hunt at 46 votes, Michael Gove at 41 votes, Rory Stewart at 37 votes and Sajid Javid at 33 votes, Dominic Raab was eliminated with 30 votes. (Newswires)

Boris Johnson and Rory Stewart became the key players in the race for No 10 last night after emerging as the winners from the MPs' vote and a heated live television debate. (Telegraph)

UK Labour party leader Corbyn will reportedly back a move for Labour to support a 2nd referendum in all circumstances. (Times)

ECB policymakers are divided on the next policy step with a rate cut, guidance change and more QE all in play, according to sources. (Newswires)

FX

DXY was steady and remained near this month’s highs after the recent Draghi-induced selling in EUR/USD and amid US-China trade hopes. As such, EUR/USD languished below the 1.1200 handle. GBP/USD was little changed overnight although recently found reprieve from support near 1.2500 and JPY-crosses were kept afloat by the risk appetite. Antipodeans also held on to the prior day’s gains due to their high-beta statuses and amid upside in commodities, but with further advances during Asia hours restricted ahead of today’s FOMC and amid more dovish calls on the RBA with AMP forecasting unemployment to increase to 5.5% and the Cash Rate to be lowered 3 more times to 0.50% by February 2020. Meanwhile, TRY weakened around 1% in late trade with the currency spooked by news that US President Trump is considering sanctions on Turkey for purchasing Russian S-400 missile systems.

COMMODITIES 

Commodities were mostly supported overnight with WTI crude futures back above the USD 54.00/bbl level amid ECB stimulus hopes and US-China trade optimism, while a slightly narrower than expected draw in headline API stockpiles did little to dent oil prices. Elsewhere, there is still a lack of unison in terms of the next producer meeting as OPEC+ members were initially said to discuss July 10th-12th as the dates for the anticipated meeting, although sources later suggested July 1st-2nd could be proposed. Gold prices were flat overnight ahead of today’s FOMC and as the greenback held firm, while copper remained near this month’s highs due to the risk appetite which also spurred a 5% rally in Dalian iron ore futures at the open.

API Crude inventories -0.81mln vs. Exp. -1.1mln (Prev. +4.9mln). (Newswires)

OPEC is said to propose holding meeting on July 1st-2nd, according to sources. (Newswires)

Reports note a rocket hit a foreign oil company headquarters in Basra, Iraq. However, officials later stated that Iraq's southern oil operations and exports were not impacted by the rocket incident. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Secretary of State Pompeo said the US will maintain the pressure campaign on Iran but also stated that the US has been engaged in many messages with Iran and does not want a war. In related news, US Special Envoy for Iran Hook plans to travel to Paris next week for talks on Iran with British, French and German officials, while there were separate comments Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Head Salami that ballistic missiles are capable of hitting carriers in the sea with great precision. (Newswires)

US President Trump is considering sanctions on Turkey for purchasing Russian S-400s. (Newswires)

US

The curve bull-flattened at settlement, with yields falling across the curve. The complex took influence from the Bund in the European morning after a dovish set of comments from ECB chief Draghi (more stimulus could be on the way unless the data improves), which eventually led to Bund yields hitting fresh record lows, before paring back as risk sentiment improved as Trump signalled progress was being made with China on trade ahead of the G20 meeting. Treasuries, however, remained bid, and 10-year yields fell to a whisker of the psychological 2.00% mark. 3m/10yr inversion deepened by around 6bps on the day, while major curve spreads were narrower by around 1-2bps at settlement. US T-note futures (M9) settled 5+ higher at 127-04+.

US President Trump was said to have asked White House lawyers on options for removing Fed Chair Powell in February, although they determined that a removal would be highly questionable. In related news, US President Trump replied "let's see what he does" when asked whether he wants to demote Fed Chair Powell, while US NEC Director Kudlow commented the White House is not considering demoting Fed Chair Powell and is not taking any action to change Powell's status. (Newswires)

US Senators from both parties reached an agreement for about USD 4.5bln to address the surge in border migrants. (Newswires)

US President Trump announced that US Acting Defence Secretary Shanahan chose to withdraw from his position. He will be replaced by Army Secretary Mark Esper. (BBC)

Asia equity markets have rallied across the board as the region follows suit to the heightened global risk appetite due to a double dosage of optimism after ECB President Draghi hinted at potential easing and US President Trump confirmed a meeting with his Chinese counterpart at the G20. ASX 200 (+1.0%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.7%) are higher with Australia led by energy names after a surge in oil prices and with outperformance also seen in the trade sensitive industries such as tech, materials and miners, while the Japanese benchmark gapped above the 21K level fuelled by favourable currency flows and strength in commodity-related sectors. DXY is steady and remains near this month’s highs after the recent Draghi-induced selling in EUR/USD and amid US-China trade hopes. As such, EUR/USD languishes just below the 1.1200 handle after ECB President Draghi paved the way for looser policy in which he suggested that additional stimulus will be needed if the outlook does not improve and that APP still has considerable headroom, while source reports suggested that ECB policymakers were divided on measures with a rate cut, guidance change and more QE all in play. GBP/USD is little changed overnight although recently found reprieve from support near 1.2500 and JPY-crosses are kept afloat by the risk appetite. Antipodeans also hold on to the prior day’s gains due to their high-beta statuses and amid upside in commodities, but with further advances during Asia hours limited ahead of today’s FOMC and amid further dovish calls on the RBA with AMP forecasting unemployment to increase to 5.5% and the Cash Rate to be lowered 3 more times to 0.50% by February 2020.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher after the dovish comments from ECB’s Draghi added to the declining global yields narrative in which 10yr JGB yields slipped to their lowest since August 2016, while the BoJ also kicks starts its 2-day policy meeting where they are expected to maintain current policy settings and reaffirm guidance of keeping rates at very low interest rate levels for an extended period of time at least through around Spring 2020.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: US President Trump confirmed he will have an extended meeting with Chinese President Xi next week at the G-20
content:
China Communications Construction (1800 HK) - Co. will acquire 3.5mln shares in a unit for CNY 2.47/Shr or total consideration of CNY 8.6bln. (Newswires)

WuXi Biologics (2269 HK) - Co. announces 55mln share offering priced at HKD 69.30/Shr vs. last close HKD 72.95/Shr. (Newswires)

Trade

US President Trump tweeted that he had a very good telephone conversation with President Xi of China and will be having an extended meeting next week at the G-20, while he also noted that their respective teams will begin talks prior to the meeting and later reiterated that the US will either have a fair deal with China or no deal at all. (Newswires)

Chinese state media confirmed that President Xi held a call with US President Trump and that Chinese President Xi has agreed to talk with US President Trump during the G20 Summit, while there were later reports that Chinese President Xi stressed that talks need to be on equal footing to solve China-US trade dispute. (Newswires/Twitter/Xinhua)

China Global Times Editor noted in a tweet which was later deleted, that the US and Chinese Presidents did agree to meet in which they will discuss fundamental issues in China-US relations, while the editor suggested the phone call brings a slim hope to break the current deadlock between the two countries. (Twitter)

USTR Lighthizer reaffirmed no decision has yet been made on implementing the next round of tariffs on Chinese goods, while he suggested that dialogue has proven to be unsuccessful in achieving trade reform with China and that he is unsure if tariffs alone will stop China cheating but it is the best instrument available. (Newswires)

US NEC Director Kudlow said US wants to continue China talks to address structural changes and enforcement, while he added that the US position remains that China must make structural changes and USTR Lighthizer will be in touch with Chinese counterparts on trade talks. (Fox News)

Other News

Hong Kong Chief Executive Lam apologised for the divisions caused by the extradition bill and said there is currently no timetable for the bill. Lam also stated that the government will definitely not resume the extradition bill if divisions cannot be resolved and it is unlikely that the bill will be able to make deadline of the end of this legislative term, while she added the extradition bill will expire if it does not reach legislature in current terms. (Newswires)
